questions.question_text: Which order of operations deletes a VI Workload Domain from a VMware Cloud Foundation environment?

choices.D:
1. Migrate VMs.
2. Decommission hosts.
3. Remove the Workload Domain.
4. Delete the network pool.
choices.A:
1. Migrate VMs.
2. Remove NSX Edge clusters.
3. Remove the Workload Domain.
4. Decommission hosts.
5. Delete the network pool.
choices.C:
1. Migrate VMs.
2. Remove the Workload Domain.
3. Decommission hosts.
4. Delete the network pool.
choices.B:
1. Migrate VMs.
2. Remove NSX Edge clusters.
3. Remove the Workload Domain.
4. Delete the network pool.
5. Decommission hosts.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Can't delete network pool if being used by hosts, need to remove hosts before pool can be deleted

B
First you delete the Network Pool and then decom the esxi hosts

Selected Answer: A
The network pools used by the workload domain are not deleted as part of the VI workload domain deletion process and must be deleted separately.
The network pools used by the workload domain are not deleted as part of the VI workload domain deletion process and must be deleted separately.

choices.D: Host overlay IP pool can be shared with the Edge overlay IP pool.
choices.B: Additional NICs will have to be added to the ESXi hosts to separate the system and NSX traffic.
choices.A: Two VLANs are needed for ESXi and edge TEP traffic.
choices.C: One VLAN can be used for both ESXi and edge TEP traffic.

discussion.content: A. Two VLANs are needed for ESXi and edge TEP traffic.

C cloud be the correct

If Edge VM TEP interface connected to a logical switch/segment on a NVDS with NSX-T 3.1.0 or above and is on a host prepared for NSX.

Any other way, ESXi TEP and Edge TEP must be on separate VLANs.

Edge TEP and ESXi host TEP must be on separate VLANs in the following configurations:

 - Edge VM TEP interface connected to a vDS portgroup where that vDS is used by NSX-T
 - Edge VM TEP interface connected to a logical switch on vDS/NVDS prior to NSX-T 3.1.0

https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/83743

questions.question_text:
An administrator is planning to enable vSphere with Tanzu on an existing VI workload domain. The following information is known:

• There is one vSphere cluster in that domain where all ESXi hosts have two uplinks.
• The NSX edge cluster will be deployed on the same vSphere cluster.
• Both System and NSX traffic will use the same uplinks of the VDS switch spanning the ESXi hosts.

Which statement accurately describes the deployment of this NSX edge cluster?

An administrator is creating a VI Workload Domain where NSX-T must be configured to allow for dynamic routing.

Which pre-requisites are required?

choices.A: Two MPLS peers on ToR switches with an interface IP and an iBGP Autonomous System Number
choices.D: Reserved BGP Autonomous System Number to use for the NSX-T Edge cluster’s Tier-0 gateway
choices.C: Separate VLANs and subnets available for NSX-T Host Overlay TEP VLAN and NSX-T Edge Overlay TEP VLAN
choices.B: Two BGP peers on ToR switches with an interface IP and BGP Autonomous System Number

discussion.content:
B
For dynamic routing, set up two Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) peers on Top of Rack (ToR) switches with an interface IP, BGP autonomous system number (ASN), and BGP password.

comments.content: Even though the answer is missing the 'BGP Password", B seems to be the correct answer.

discussion.content:
B is correct

For dynamic routing, set up two Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) peers on Top of Rack (ToR) switches with an interface IP, BGP autonomous system number (ASN), and BGP password.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-
Foundation/5.1/com.vmware.vcf.vxrail.doc/GUID-D6271E5A-05E9-4AE1-A3CE-87820DC3001B.html

Selected Answer: B
Correct Answer is B

Correct Answer is B. The question is to 'Dynamic Routing' not all pre-requisites.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/5.0/com.vmware.vcf.vxrail.doc/GUID-D6271E5A-05E9-4AE1-A3CE-87820DC3001B.html

questions.question_text:
An architect is presented with a Bill of Material for different vSAN ready nodes:
8 identical nodes with 1 vSAN disk group
8 identical nodes with 2 vSAN disk groups
What is the ideal design of VMware Cloud Foundation domains that the architect should recommend?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is a best answer:

Based on VCF Domain Requirement and vSAN Cluster Practice, 4x Nodes will be a Managemnet Domain (Min. Requirement 4 Nodes) other 4x Nodes (with 1 Disk Group) and 8x Nodes (with 2 Disk Groups) seperate 2x Workload Domain because vSAN Best Pratices same cluster should be same numebr disk group and same number of Cache and Capacity (same size) each host .

choices.D: 1 Management Domain of 4 nodes, 1 Workload Domain of 4 nodes, and 1 Workload Domain of 8 nodes
choices.C: 1 Domain of 16 nodes deployed on a Consolidated Architecture model
choices.A: 1 Management Domain of 6 Nodes, 1 Workload Domain of 4 nodes, and 1 Workload Domain of 6 nodes
choices.B: 1 Management Domain of 6 nodes and 1 Workload Domain of 10 nodes

questions.question_text:
An administrator is deploying a new VMware Cloud Foundation workload domain.

Which three options are supported for supplemental storage? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
CDE is correct for me

However, A is right too.

Selected Answer: ACE
Shared Storage Types Supported for VI Workload Domains
Storage Type

Supported as Principal Storage

Supported as Supplemental Storage

Traditional Storage

Fibre Channel and NFS are applicable options for the principal storage for the VI workload domain.

iSCSI storage is currently not supported.

Fibre Channel

NFS

iSCSI

comments.content:
So the problem is that we have 4 correct answers, ACDE. Keep in mind this test is on 4.x, not 5.x. 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.5/vcf-vi-workload-domain-design/GUID-2091F2E2-D53A-4A92-BD3B-C158F6E367DF.html

They don't list "VMFS on iSCSI", but "iSCSI" is on there (supplemental for both MGMT and VI), implied it would be formatted with VMFS

I'd probably enter ACD as presented on the exam.

I agree, VMF on iSCSI is not on the list

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.5/vcf-admin/GUID-4EBF9094-F732-4800-86FF-30C5D88B9758.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CDE
Not seeing VMFS on iSCSI on the list 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/5.0/vcf-design/GUID-2156EC66-BBBB-4197-91AD-660315385D2E.html
